title: Legit Starting To Actually Hate This Game
body:
It's supposed to be a "team game", why is it that I am constantly matched with unresponsive teammates? Every game feels like I have absolutely no team at all. My teammates are unwilling to contribute, they don't pay attention, they don't do anything. I'm so fed up and tired of it. I try desperately to help my team, but they don't even help themselves. Why am I playing this game?

Getting invaded by the enemy team? You can bet my team won't be there.

Going anywhere to gank a lane? You can bet my team isn't going to engage, they aren't even going to move.

Trying to get my team to help obtain a neutral objective? Maybe next game, next year, next life. Sure doesn't happen in my games.

Every single thing that pisses me off in this game is related to how team oriented it is. Without my team, I am helpless. The enemy team shits on me in my Jungle and there is nothing I can do about it. It's impossible to snowball my own laners, because they either don't want me to gank, or aren't paying attention when I do come to their lane. Something happens, I know we can get that objective, my team doesn't want to help. This game is horrible. Either I get really fed and I solo carry a bunch of people who don't deserve it, or the enemy team goon squads my Jungle and prevents me from being able to do anything. 

It's getting to the point where it's predictable, and not even fun anymore. I can tell by 5 minutes into the game if I've won or lost, then if the game is not looking well, I'm forced to sit around in a long ass 20-30 minute miserable game. Such a massive waste of time.

Considering that i also play Vi in the jungle, your build does seem a bit problematic.
The issue i'm having is that with what you're building, you're really trying to double down on her damage and forgo any survivability as a Bruiser. This doesn't work for Vi most of the times as you suddenly drop off the face of the damage map if the game goes for longer, due to how everyone else scales and as a Bruiser and a Diver, you need to also be tanky to be able to survive the damage.

I've tried Vi with a lot of different builds and runes and there's just nothing better than the regular Bruiser build. It's expensive as shit (and one of the reasons why bruisers feel so bad to play currently) but it is what it is. Vi has no options to back down once she's in the fight and you need to make sure you're either engaging a priority target to which your team can follow up on or you can take out the target/make the enemy focus you while your team cleans house.

This is stupid. Who is at fault then? The universe? Luck?

Yes actually you ARE responsible. A car is a machine - and therefore not unpredictable. If the car breaks down then it was overused/abused and did not have proper upkeep. 

A better analogy: Humans are unpredictable - so something like a _car accident_ is _sometimes_ out of your control.

However, if you get in 15 car accidents in 1 year while the average guy gets in, let’s say, 1 - then you’re _probably_ just a shit driver. Is it possible that you’re really unlucky and you actually drive well? Yes. But realistically you are probably doing dumb shit which leads to those accidents.

It's not always solo laners, it could be any lane, but for sake of example that's what I'm using. 

Sometimes those people get big, they carry the game, but the vast majority of the time they do not. The game requires a team, and even though they won lane things go down hill quickly because they simply cannot 1v5 when the rest of their team got their asses handed to them. Literally all of it could be prevented if they'd simply play with their teammates and actively contribute to the game.

To me, working together as a team, having teammates who pay attention and are responsive to events around the map, having teammates who work to keep everything together when misplays are made, that is more important than risking everything on one player who actually thinks they can super man the team on their back and hard carry the entire game.

the main issue is that there IS a correlation between skill and climbing if you map it out on a spreadsheet. If my personal skill in relation to my team is a 5.5, and I raise it to a 7.5, 8, or even 9, I will win more games on average. However, and this is the problem - your team isn't always a 5 on average. Sometimes they're a 4. Sometimes they're a 3. Sometimes they're a 2. So you can win the games where you are a 7, and your team is a 4, and their team is a 4.5 on average (23 > 22.5). Okay. Gotta carry to climb. What if your team is a 3? Now you don't win. 19 > 22.5. 

The issue is this *feels* bad, and just like with champs, what *feels* bad is often more important than the statistical reality. When you get 3-4 games in a row where your team is a 2, 3, 4, and your skill level is a 5.5 or 6 or 6.5, then it feels like shit, and it doesn't matter that the stats will regress to the mean and you'll climb over the long haul, we're humans, not machines, and not everyone can deal with that cycle of frustration and helplessness, especially when you put a lot of time and effort into getting better, and getting better doesn't generate an immediate, dopamine-pumping reward (like say, the enemy nexus blowing up, or you dunking on the enemy team), or only generates one over the super long haul. Now, does this negate the fact that you'll win games if your skill level is 7.5 that you won't at 6.5? No. Obviously you can get better (though realistically, not everyone has the time or dedication to get to say, mid Diamond in skill level, which would be an 7-8 compared to the 5 that is Silver-Gold). But it is frustrating, and frustration sucks the fun out of competition.
